content.description:
A rare combination of very easy climbing and very fun movement.  Would be better if it was less dirty.

Follow the huge right facing crack/corner to its end, then head up slab until you reach the slanting crack / alcove where you can set a belay.

Guidebook describes this as a good beginner lead - maybe it was at the time, but I would not recommend it to new leaders in its current (May 2018) state.  When I climbed this the crack was full of moss and after the crack ends the next half of the pitch is (very easy) unprotected slab.  Finally the belay crack was thin and a bit mossy, and the walk off is pretty exposed.  Good climb, but not a good beginner lead in my opinion due to above factors.
content.location: Huge right facing crack/corner on right (South) side of the West Face.

content.description:
Karl Palsson writes: "...[this] is a mega classic. Really really nice climbing.

Stunning to be climbing in afternoon sun too [though it makes the descent in the dark a littler harder :) ]

A Couple of updates to the HW108 guide.

There's actually 6 bolts on the first pitch, an extra one between the marked 3 and 4, and between the marked 4 and the belay.

The anchor at the top of P1 is a 3bb not a 2bb as marked in the guide.

The second pitch is much straighter than it appears in the guide, and has an extra third bolt

The pitches do NOT get shorter, contrary to what the book may appear to show :)

They do however, get easier.

The third belay is quite crusty and arbitrary, if you are climbing in daylight, you would probably start simul climbing here and be done with it. All gear is thin and marginal. Biggest piece we used was a #1 tricam.

Also, the big 12' high column marked in the topo is more to the right, closer to the top of the climb than is shown.

This info is(was) correct as at 2 - Sept - 2001."
content.protection: 1 set of cams 1/2" - 1", an extra 1/2"-3/4" cam,  and a few slings. First 2 pitches have bolted anchors, but you will need to build a trad anchor at top of pitches 3 and 4.
